div.head:
Embleme 43. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Give ear to the Vultur's words, which are noewise false.

lg.l: The Vultur on the mountaine stands in sight,
Himselfe proclaiming daily, blacke, and white,
Citrine, and red; nor false: The Raven is
The same, which without wings by nature flyes
In dismall darkenesse, and in glorious light,
For either will to th' art conduct you right.

div.head: Discourse 43.
div.ab:
Wee daily in many places hear birds prattling or imitating the voyce
of man, such as Parrotts, Ravens, Dawes, and Pyes. Soe Pliny writes-
that, at the time wherein hee published his history, Agrippina the-
wife of Claudius Cæsar had a thrush, imitating the speech of men.-
The young Cæsars had allso a Starling and Nightingales accustomed to
the Greeke and Latine tongue, and daily speaking new things, with-
a long forme of words allso. But such birds now frequently happening
they are thought lesse worthy of admiration, for all birds endu'd-
with a broad tongue may by use and custome be brought to speake
and babble. But that Vultur, which the Philosophers make mention
of, did not learne words, if any hee utters, by use, but his nature tacit
ly expresseth them. The Philosophers doe indeed say, that hee-
continually cryes out, and with a loud Voyce pronounceth, who and
what hee is, wherein hee imitates great Princes, who in the begining
of their intimations will allwayes make their titles and inheritances-
knowne, not in token of any pride, but for other reasons, that they-
allso themselves may know, what principalityes they governe, or-
right of inheritance they prætend to: Soe it is very materiall to-
know, what colours, as ensigns of armes and titles, the Philosophi
call bird is adornd with, and wherein hee excells all others. I, Sayth hee,
as Rosarius hath it from Hermes, am the blacke of white, and the ci
trine of red, and certainly I speake truth and lye not. Hee affirmes
himselfe blacke, white, citrine, and red, and such hee really is, for-
though hee doth not as yet actually possesse the last colours, yet hee
expects the inheritance of them: Hereupon Sayth Rosinus in his booke
of divine interpretations; Take the Stone, which is blacke, white,-
red, citrine, that admirable bird, which flyes without wings in the
darknesse of the night, and clearnesse of the day: For coloration-
ariseth from the bitternesse which is in his throat, but mere water-
proceeds from his blood, as Alexander sayd. Take (My Sonne) the
Stone of four colours. The Philosophers books doe abundantly de
clare and insinuate that the Stone hath all these colours, which
are principall, in a successive order. But why the Philosophicall
subject is calld a Vultur, there is reason to be alleadged. Of Vulturs-
the blacke are of most esteem, they are rapacious, but fly Slowly, be
cause of the bignesse of body. They say that this bird conceives-
without the seed of the males, and generates without coition, and
that their offspring doe arrive to a great age even to a hundred-
years. Their nests they build in high rocks, noe man hath attained
to them. Two chickens are for the most part seen: They are helpe
full and commodious agaynst Serpents. They are offended and-
Discourse 43.
perplexed with the East wind. When they begin to lay eggs, they-
bring a thing out of the Indyes, which is as a nutt, having within a-
thing that may be moved, and forthwith yeild a sound, which when
they have applyed to them, they produce many young chickens,-
but one onely remayns, which is calld Immusulus. Hermodorus Fon
ticus in Cælius is a wittnesse, that Vulturs of all animalls are the-
most innocent, because they doe not at all meddle with any of those
things which men sow, plant, and breed. Moreover they kill noe-
animalls. They allso abstaine from birds though dead by a certaine
instinct of affinity: For this cause they were best esteemd in divina
tions, as the originalls of the Citty of Rome declare. The Philoso
phicall bird expressing allmost all these propertyes of Vulturs, is
therefore by Hermes and others not undeservedly called Vultur, which
is allso slow in flight, and blacke of colour; It conceives by itselfe:
For thus sayth Rosarius about the end; And it is the Dragon, which
wedds itselfe, and impregnats itselfe, and brings forth in its owne
season Ct. And Rosinus to Sarratant: And that is the Serpent, ad
ministring pleasure to itselfe, impregnating itselfe, and bringing
forth in one day, Ct. It lives and endures a very long time, and-
multiplyes itselfe. For that which Virgill writes of the bird calld
a Phænix, is as proper to this, because it is the same.
Alipedem Cervum Corvus ter vincit, at illum
Multiplicat novies Phænix reparabilis abes.
Three ages of a Hart the Raven lives,
Which the rare Phænix nine times 'ore survives.
It is very difficult to climbe this birds nest: It fights with the Mercuriall
serpent, and overcomes it, that is, Sol with Luna. It is conceived by-
the wind, and carryed in its belly, and bred in the aire. The-
Stone Ælites, containing a little stone sounding within it is by many
men called Totium. One onely Immusulus is found in the Philoso
phers nest. The Philosophicke bird is allso most innocent, because
it hurts noe body, it is beneficiall to all that know it, and most ex
cellent in divinations. But why doth it make its nest on a Mountaine,
and sitting soe cry out? Rosinus answers according to Rasis, who sayth.
Behold the most high mountains, which are both on the right and
left, and climbe up thither: There is our Stone found, and in another
mountaine, which produceth all sorts of Painter colours, and Spirits-
or Species, there likewise it is: Morienus: Climbe up the high mountains,
planted wih trees, because there is our stone found, and hidden: And Hermes:
Take yee the blessed Stone, breake it to peices, and wash the red stone, from
which is extracted that which is found in mountains, and especially sometimes in old Sinks.
